data.text:
Based on Hamel Husain's recommendation, I built up a super simple UI to grade transcripts (PASS / FAIL + free text critique) and it already yielded valuable insights with just 10 grades.

Next step: spin up more traces (real human + sim testing) and do a proper error matrix analysis. Using agentic workflows, of course üèãÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

Continue to be astounded by what's possible with Anthropic's Claude Code + a few skills and MCPs. Best part: the "Claude skills" (and coding skillz) stack like Legos so when I learn a cool new trick I can layer that into all my projects quickly and efficiently.

SO COOL!

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

data.text:
Read through Hamel Husain's writings on evals and he brings up excellent points I see in production and POC Voice AI agents.

Most importantly: start evals with a single SME (aka the benevolent dictator) doing pass / fail + detailed free text critique. 

I've definitely bogged down my team with too many metrics I had to claw back. üôÑ 

Another interesting one is building custom UIs that surface just the right context and trace logging for your dictator üëÜ . Haven't done that yet but it's a fantastic point.

Generally, Hamel's writing is some of the best I've see on running effective LLM evals. If you're in this space, def take a look!

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

data.text:
Evals aren't a technical problem - they're a product management opportunity.

Hot take from Brooke Hopkins and Hamel Husain's podcast on evals that immediately resonated with my experience managing Voice AI initiatives. My top 8 takeaways:

1. **Lead with outcomes.** If your team can't articulate what "excellent" looks like for your agent, get the team aligned on what your agent does (and doesn't!) do.

2. **Evals are product management in disguise.** They're cross-functional and touch every team that drives inputs and downstream workflows (eng, marketing, sales, CS, operations, etc).

3. **Most teams underinvest.** 60-80% of your time should go toward defining and testing for success. Evals are the bottleneck for most teams.

4. **Fix upstream first.** Focus on the earliest error in a trace, especially in cascading architectures like voice stacks.

5. **n-1 testing is naive.** Reproducing errors in fewer turns reduces complexity and gives you a cleaner signal.

6. **Sims with states get expensive fast.** Managing evals at scale means balancing speed, latency, signal, and cost.

7. **Evals are a spectrum.** You want "hill climbing" problems just above and below current capabilities, plus happy path and adversarial cases for both existing wins and aspirational paths.

8. **Criteria drift is real.** Users adapt expectations based on capabilities they experience. Approached right, this is a feature, not a flaw! 

High yield conversation for just 30 minutes, and spot on from what I'm seeing at the frontlines of building and deploying enterprise Voice AI. 

I'm looking forward to reading Hamel's blog and scope his evals course.

üîó  Link to podcast in comments

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

data.text:
I co-wrote an article with Keith Ferrazzi on teamship for AI-human hybrid teams and it was on Inc. Magazine's homepage on Sunday.

Some things that work for humans don't make as much sense for AI teammates (eg psychological safety). But many of the social contracts that make human teams effective also work with hybrid teams - they just need to be conceived of and applied differently.

We cover 5 teamship archetypes from Keith's book Never Lead Alone:
- The Facilitator
- The Reviewer
- The Coach
- The Cheerleader
- The Contributor

As AI agents become more embedded in teams, we need to adapt high performing teams to collaborate effectively with a new kind of teammate.

For those running hybrid human-AI teams, how are you structuring team dynamics? When do you deploy agents in team conversations / working sessions, and when do you keep the room human-only? I'm working on these questions in my team, and would love to compare notes.

üîó  Link to the article in the comments below

We are excited to share more about how CloudTrucks uses Operator's AI agents to streamline and scale their phone operations. 

Scaling freight ops used to mean scaling call centers. CloudTrucks chose software instead. Their partnership with Operator delivered:

- 100% inbound coverage for drivers, brokers, and sales
- Unified phone layer across all teams‚Äîcustomer ops, safety, and GTM
- AI platform to continue automating more workflows

Freight and logistics leaders who are looking to adopt AI agents in a thoughtful way can read the blueprint here: https://lnkd.in/gaG3BkFE

Building out AI Voice Agents is no simple feat. The Operator team have been great partners as we continue to put drivers first and provide the best possible sales and support experience.

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

resharedPost.text:
Today, we're introducing an upgraded Claude 3.5 Sonnet, and a new model, Claude 3.5 Haiku. We‚Äôre also introducing a new capability in public beta: computer use. With computer use, developers can direct Claude to use computers the way people do‚Äîby looking at a screen, moving a cursor, clicking, and typing text.

The new Claude 3.5 Sonnet is the first frontier AI model to offer computer use in public beta.

While groundbreaking, computer use is still experimental‚Äîat times error-prone. We're releasing it early for feedback from developers.

We've built an API that allows Claude to perceive and interact with computer interfaces. This API enables Claude to translate prompts into computer commands. Developers can use it to automate repetitive tasks, conduct testing and QA, and perform open-ended research.

We're trying something fundamentally new. Instead of making specific tools to help Claude complete individual tasks, we're teaching it general computer skills‚Äîallowing it to use a wide range of standard tools and software programs designed for people.

Claude 3.5 Sonnet's current ability to use computers is imperfect. Some actions that people perform effortlessly‚Äîscrolling, dragging, zooming‚Äîcurrently present challenges. We encourage exploration with low-risk tasks.

Beyond computer use, the new Claude 3.5 Sonnet delivers significant gains in coding‚Äîan area where it already led the field. Sonnet scores higher on SWE-bench Verified than all available models‚Äîincluding reasoning models like OpenAI o1-preview and specialized models for agentic coding.

Claude 3.5 Haiku is the next generation of our fastest model. Haiku now outperforms many state-of-the-art models on coding tasks‚Äîincluding the original Claude 3.5 Sonnet and GPT-4o‚Äîat the same cost as before. The new Claude 3.5 Haiku will be released later this month.

We believe these developments will open up new possibilities for how you work with Claude, and we look forward to seeing what you'll create.

Read the updates in full: https://lnkd.in/dBDxDTZF

data.text: This is a fascinating move and huge. Can't wait to see how this will impact knowledge work and team collaboration.

data.text:
#AISkills are the new corporate currency. Hint: NOT the same as coding AI.

@company_bain-and-company's 2024 Tech Report[1] talks about the need for hiring and upskilling. But it doesn't go into too much detail on specifics.

üé≠ First, a haiku appetizer :)
Skills evolve with AI
Old roles fade, new ones emerge
Adapt or get left

Here is my breakdown:

ùó®ùóªùó∂ùòÉùó≤ùóøùòÄùóÆùóπ ùó¶ùó∏ùó∂ùóπùóπùòÄ (ùóòùòÉùó≤ùóøùòÜùóºùóªùó≤ ùóªùó≤ùó≤ùó±ùòÄ ùòÅùóµùó≤ùòÄùó≤)
‚Ä¢ Task decomposition: Break it down before you build it up.
‚Ä¢ Prompting: The art of asking AI the right questions.
‚Ä¢ Output evaluation: Because AI can be confidently wrong.

ùó•ùóºùóπùó≤-ùó¶ùóΩùó≤ùó∞ùó∂ùó≥ùó∂ùó∞ ùó¶ùó∏ùó∂ùóπùóπùòÄ (ùóßùóÆùó∂ùóπùóºùóøùó≤ùó± ùòÅùóº ùòÜùóºùòÇùóø ùó∑ùóºùóØ)
Some high level examples include
‚Ä¢ Managers: AI-powered coaching and project management
‚Ä¢ Developers: API integrations and LLM Ops
‚Ä¢ Marketers: AI-driven content creation and personalization

ùó¢ùóøùó¥ùóÆùóªùó∂ùòáùóÆùòÅùó∂ùóºùóªùóÆùóπ ùó¶ùó∏ùó∂ùóπùóπùòÄ (ùóñùóºùó∫ùóΩùóÆùóªùòÜ-ùòÑùó∂ùó±ùó≤ ùó∫ùòÇùòÄùó∞ùóπùó≤ùòÄ)
‚Ä¢ Cross-functional collaboration: Break down those silos!
‚Ä¢ Continuous learning: Because AI doesn't stand still.
‚Ä¢ Risk management: Mitigate before you automate.

üí° Standout quote: "ùëÄùëéùëõùëéùëîùëñùëõùëî ‚Ñéùëúùë§ ùëíùëöùëùùëôùëúùë¶ùëíùëíùë† ùëê‚Ñéùëéùëõùëîùëí ùë°‚Ñéùëíùëñùëü ùëèùëí‚Ñéùëéùë£ùëñùëúùëüùë† ùëêùëéùëõ ùëöùëéùëòùëí ùëúùëü ùëèùëüùëíùëéùëò ùëéùëõ ùëéùë¢ùë°ùëúùëöùëéùë°ùëñùëúùëõ ùëùùëüùëúùëîùëüùëéùëö. ùëÄùëéùë•ùëñùëöùëñùëßùëñùëõùëî ùëéùëëùëúùëùùë°ùëñùëúùëõ ùëúùëì ùëéùë¢ùë°ùëúùëöùëéùë°ùëñùëúùëõ ùë°ùëúùëúùëôùë† ùëíùëõùë°ùëéùëñùëôùë† ùëëùëúùëêùë¢ùëöùëíùëõùë°ùëñùëõùëî ùëéùëõùëë ùëíùëëùë¢ùëêùëéùë°ùëñùëõùëî ùëùùëíùëúùëùùëôùëí ùëúùëõ ùë°‚Ñéùëí ùëõùëíùë§ ùë§ùëéùë¶ ùë°ùëú ùë§ùëúùëüùëò, ùëñùëõùë£ùëíùë†ùë°ùëñùëõùëî ùëñùëõ ùë°ùëüùëéùëñùëõùëñùëõùëî, ùë°ùëüùëéùëêùëòùëñùëõùëî ùëéùëëùëúùëùùë°ùëñùëúùëõ ùëüùëéùë°ùëíùë†, ùëéùëõùëë ùë°ùëéùëòùëñùëõùëî ùë†ùë°ùëíùëùùë† ùë°ùëú ùëòùëíùëíùëù ùëñùëöùëùùëüùëúùë£ùëñùëõùëî ‚Ñéùëúùë§ ùëùùëíùëúùëùùëôùëí ùë¢ùë†ùëí ùë°‚Ñéùëí ùë°ùëíùëê‚Ñéùëõùëúùëôùëúùëîùëñùëíùë†."

Here are 5 steps to level up your org's #AISkills:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Map skills to your AI maturity curve. Know where you are and where you're going.
2Ô∏è‚É£ Invest in prompt engineering training. Everyone is doing it ...
3Ô∏è‚É£ Create AI playgrounds. Safe spaces to experiment and learn. Then put those learnings to work.
4Ô∏è‚É£ Develop AI champions in each department and team. Spread the knowledge!
5Ô∏è‚É£ Regularly reassess and update your skill matrix. AI moves fast, so should you.

Remember: In the AI age, the most valuable skill is learning how to learn.

What #AISkills are you prioritizing? Drop your thoughts in the comments!

data.text:
@company_bain-and-company's 2024 Tech Report[1] emphasizes the importance of a structured approach to #GenAI strategy. 

Let's break it down:
üéØ ùêíùê≠ùêöùê´ùê≠ ùê∞ùê¢ùê≠ùê° ùêö ùêúùê•ùêûùêöùê´ ùêØùê¢ùê¨ùê¢ùê®ùêß: Define how AI aligns with your business goals. This isn't just another tech project - it's a fundamental shift in how you operate.
üó∫Ô∏è ùêåùêöùê© ùê≤ùê®ùêÆùê´ ùêÄùêà ùê¶ùêöùê≠ùêÆùê´ùê¢ùê≠ùê≤ ùêúùêÆùê´ùêØùêû: Understand where you are and where you're headed. This isn't a one-size-fits-all journey.
üèóÔ∏è ùêÅùêÆùê¢ùê•ùêù ùêö ùê´ùê®ùêõùêÆùê¨ùê≠ ùêÄùêà ùê¢ùêßùêüùê´ùêöùê¨ùê≠ùê´ùêÆùêúùê≠ùêÆùê´ùêû: Re-architect your tech stack with an "AI everywhere" approach. This includes data analytics, ML systems, and integration capabilities.
üîç ùêàùêùùêûùêßùê≠ùê¢ùêüùê≤ ùêöùêßùêù ùê©ùê´ùê¢ùê®ùê´ùê¢ùê≠ùê¢ùê≥ùêû ùêÆùê¨ùêû ùêúùêöùê¨ùêûùê¨: Focus on use case families that align with your business goals. Remember, it's about scaling wins, not just individual successes.
"ùëÖùëéùë°‚Ñéùëíùëü ùë°‚Ñéùëéùëõ ùëôùëúùëúùëòùëñùëõùëî ùëéùë° ùëîùëíùëõùëíùëüùëéùë°ùëñùë£ùëí ùê¥ùêº ùëúùëùùëùùëúùëüùë°ùë¢ùëõùëñùë°ùëñùëíùë† ùëèùë¶ ùëñùëõùëëùëñùë£ùëñùëëùë¢ùëéùëô ùë¢ùë†ùëí ùëêùëéùë†ùëíùë†, ùëôùëíùëéùëëùëíùëüùë† ùë£ùëñùëíùë§ ùë°‚Ñéùëíùëö ùëñùëõ ùëìùëéùëöùëñùëôùëñùëíùë†‚Äîùë°‚Ñéùëéùë° ùëñùë†, ùëé ùë†ùëíùë° ùëúùëì ùë¢ùë†ùëí ùëêùëéùë†ùëíùë† ùëìùëúùëêùë¢ùë†ùëíùëë ùëúùëõ ùëé ùëêùëúùëõùë°ùëñùëîùë¢ùëúùë¢ùë† ùëîùëüùëúùë¢ùëù ùëúùëì ùëùùëüùëúùëêùëíùë†ùë†ùëíùë†."

üõ†Ô∏è ùêÉùêûùêØùêûùê•ùê®ùê© ùêßùêûùêúùêûùê¨ùê¨ùêöùê´ùê≤ ùê¨ùê§ùê¢ùê•ùê•ùê¨: Upskill your team across the board. This isn't just about tech skills - it's about reimagining how work gets done.
‚öñÔ∏è ùêåùêöùêßùêöùê†ùêû ùê´ùê¢ùê¨ùê§ùê¨ ùê©ùê´ùê®ùêöùêúùê≠ùê¢ùêØùêûùê•ùê≤: Implement strong governance and monitoring. Because "the AI made me do it" isn't a valid excuse.
üîÑ ùêàùê≠ùêûùê´ùêöùê≠ùêû ùêöùêßùêù ùê¨ùêúùêöùê•ùêû: Use "mastery loops" to refine and expand your AI initiatives. This isn't a one-and-done deal - it's an ongoing journey.

Remember, early adopters are starting to see the compounding benefits of using AI in their organizations (performance gains up to 20% of earnings in 18-36 months!). 

Hype is distracting, and diligent AI utilization can yield significant benefits and profits. What's your biggest challenge in implementing a Gen AI strategy? Share in the comments!

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

data.text:
Let's talk #AIRisks. @company_bain-and-company's 2024 Tech Report[1] doesn't sugarcoat it: AI risks are structural.

Much of the focus is on privacy, national security, energy and compute, spurring sovereign AI discussions. 

Drilling this down to business leaders, here are some key points worth considering for your AI strategy.

ü™Ü ùêëùêÆùê¨ùê¨ùê¢ùêöùêß ùêÉùê®ùê•ùê• ùêÑùêüùêüùêûùêúùê≠ - Each step up the AI maturity curve, and each family of #AIUseCases, adds a new layer of risk. Manage those risks early and often.
üîç ùêêùêÆùêöùê•ùê¢ùê≠ùê≤ ùêÇùê®ùêßùê≠ùê´ùê®ùê• ùêåùêöùê≠ùê≠ùêûùê´ùê¨ - Garbage in, garbage out. But now it's worse - you might feed sensitive data to third-party vendors or pollinate poisons through agents. Design and enforce human oversight guidelines.
üîê ùêÉùêöùê≠ùêö ùêÜùê®ùêØùêûùê´ùêßùêöùêßùêúùêû - AI is most powerful when it has access to your proprietary data. Tightly control what the models can access and what they can do with that data. AI is like that one colleague who talks too much and doesn't take security training seriously (you know who I'm talking about).
üí§ ùêíùê•ùêûùêûùê©ùê≤ ùêñùê°ùêûùêûùê• ùêíùê≤ùêßùêùùê´ùê®ùê¶ùêû - Humans may become over-reliant on AI outputs. Don't fall asleep at the wheel!

Standout quote:
"ùê¥ùë† ùëîùëíùëõùëíùëüùëéùë°ùëñùë£ùëí ùê¥ùêº ùëöùëúùëëùëíùëô ùë¢ùë†ùëí ùëêùëéùë†ùëíùë† ùëîùëíùë° ùëëùëíùëùùëôùëúùë¶ùëíùëë ùëéùëêùëüùëúùë†ùë† ùëêùëüùëñùë°ùëñùëêùëéùëô ùë†ùë¶ùë†ùë°ùëíùëöùë† ùëéùëõùëë ùëêùëúùëöùëùùëôùëíùë•ùëñùë°ùë¶ ùëñùëõùëêùëüùëíùëéùë†ùëíùë† (ùëìùëúùëü ùëíùë•ùëéùëöùëùùëôùëí, ùëëùëéùëñùë†ùë¶-ùëê‚Ñéùëéùëñùëõùëíùëë ùê¥ùêº ùë¢ùë†ùëí ùëêùëéùë†ùëíùë†), ùëñùë° ùë§ùëñùëôùëô ùëùùë¢ùë° ùëìùë¢ùëüùë°‚Ñéùëíùëü ùëëùëíùëöùëéùëõùëëùë† ùëúùëõ ùëêùëúùëôùëôùëéùëèùëúùëüùëéùë°ùëñùëúùëõ, ùëûùë¢ùëéùëôùëñùë°ùë¶ ùëêùëúùëõùë°ùëüùëúùëô, ùëüùëíùëôùëñùëéùëèùëñùëôùëñùë°ùë¶, ùëéùëõùëë ùë†ùëêùëéùëôùëéùëèùëñùëôùëñùë°ùë¶. ... ùê∂ùëôùëíùëéùëü ùëîùë¢ùëñùëëùëíùëôùëñùëõùëíùë† ùëéùëüùëí ùëüùëíùëûùë¢ùëñùëüùëíùëë ùëúùëõ ‚Ñéùëúùë§ ùë°ùëú ùëëùëíùëùùëôùëúùë¶ ùë°‚Ñéùëíùë†ùëí ùë°ùëúùëúùëôùë†, ùëüùëíùëîùë¢ùëôùëéùëüùëôùë¶ ùëöùëúùëõùëñùë°ùëúùëü ùë°‚Ñéùëíùëñùëü ùëñùëöùëùùëéùëêùë°, ùëéùëõùëë ùëöùëéùëõùëéùëîùëí ùëüùëñùë†ùëòùë†."

So, what's a responsible leader to do?

1Ô∏è‚É£ ùóñùóøùó≤ùóÆùòÅùó≤ ùó∞ùóπùó≤ùóÆùóø ùóîùóú ùó¥ùòÇùó∂ùó±ùó≤ùóπùó∂ùóªùó≤ùòÄ. Two pages of bullet points in your employee handbook isn't overkill.
2Ô∏è‚É£ ùóïùòÇùó∂ùóπùó± ùóÆ ùó∞ùòÇùóπùòÅùòÇùóøùó≤ ùóºùó≥ ùóîùóú ùóøùó∂ùòÄùó∏ ùóÆùòÑùóÆùóøùó≤ùóªùó≤ùòÄùòÄ. It's not just for the IT nerds anymore.
3Ô∏è‚É£ ùóúùó∫ùóΩùóπùó≤ùó∫ùó≤ùóªùòÅ ùòÄùòÅùóøùóºùóªùó¥ ùó¥ùóºùòÉùó≤ùóøùóªùóÆùóªùó∞ùó≤. Because "the AI made me do it" won't hold up in court.
4Ô∏è‚É£ ùó†ùóºùóªùó∂ùòÅùóºùóø, ùó∫ùóºùóªùó∂ùòÅùóºùóø, ùó∫ùóºùóªùó∂ùòÅùóºùóø. Trust, but verify (and then verify again).

Remember: With great power comes great responsibility. And potentially great lawsuits.

What's your biggest #AIRisk concern? Let's discuss in the comments!

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

data.text:
@company_bain-and-company's 2024 Tech Report[1] is chock full of valuable gen AI insights. Let's dig into effective #AIUseCases today.

üß† First, a mental model shift:
Most folks start with individual use cases. Then graduate to use case FAMILIES.

What's a use case family? It's a set of related use cases that leverage similar tech, data, and processes. This approach lets you build on early wins and scale faster.

Here are 5 use case families delivering real value right now:

‚û¢ ùêíùê®ùêüùê≠ùê∞ùêöùê´ùêû ùêÉùêûùêØùêûùê•ùê®ùê©ùê¶ùêûùêßùê≠: 15-40% productivity gains in coding, testing, and documentation. One catch - you need rich datasets beyond just the code base.
‚û¢ ùêÇùêÆùê¨ùê≠ùê®ùê¶ùêûùê´ ùêíùêÆùê©ùê©ùê®ùê´ùê≠: Up to 35% reduction in response times. By 2026, AI could handle 50% of non-voice interactions and 25-35% of simple voice interactions.
‚û¢ ùêíùêöùê•ùêûùê¨ & ùêåùêöùê´ùê§ùêûùê≠ùê¢ùêßùê†: Turbocharging personalization, content creation, and customer segmentation. One tech firm cut content creation time by 30%.
‚û¢ ùêèùê´ùê®ùêùùêÆùêúùê≠ ùêÉùêûùêØùêûùê•ùê®ùê©ùê¶ùêûùêßùê≠: Simplifying interfaces and boosting customization. Example: @company_carrefour's AI shopping assistant generates personalized lists and menu suggestions.
‚û¢ ùêÅùêöùêúùê§ ùêéùêüùêüùê¢ùêúùêû: Finance teams are seeing massive efficiency gains. Microsoft trimmed month-long forecasting from 100 FTEs to 2 FTEs in just 2 days.

üí™ Pro Tip: Don't just automate existing complexity. Fix the processes FIRST, then automate. You'll thank me later.

Proof is in the profit. Early adopters see performance gains up to 20% of earnings in 18-36 months.

So, what use case family are you tackling first?

‚Äª ‚Äª ‚Äª ‚Äª ‚Äª

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

resharedPost.text:
To get good at AI you need to use AI.

So it is heartening that AI use is a lot more democratized than most technologies: GenAI is cheap (or free) & available to billions of people with internet access. As a result, a lot of traditional equity gaps in new technology are mitigated... except the gender gap.

Women use AI significantly less than men for reasons that are not completely clear.

author.headline: Associate Professor at The Wharton School. Author of Co-Intelligence

data.text:
Why do women use gen AI less than men?

I've seen this finding in most every survey in multiple countries.

To the ladies of LinkedIn - any ideas as to why?

Is this topic ripe for mansplaining? (I'm seeing a great satire piece from Ross Pomerantz)

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

data.text:
Bain & Company's 2024 Tech Report[1] is chock full of great insights. I'll share a few each day this week. Here are today's:

‚úçüèº But first, a haiku summary 
AI reshapes tech
Value shifts, new skills emerge
Leaders forge ahead

ü§® AI isn't disrupting industries - it's disrupting workflows & processes. Oh, and leaders who aren't thinking critically about expensive digital snake oil. 

Here are 5 no-BS takeaways for C-suite execs:

‚û¢ Early AI adopters are seeing 20% earnings boosts in 18-36 months. There are some benefits to waiting to overcome early adopter mistakes. Still, the compounding benefits of AI adoption mean many more benefits to starting and scaling before the competitive moat is insurmountable. 
‚û¢ Forget modest goals. Set bold targets for AI initiatives, framing potential in millions of dollars. Then recognize this benefit is built brick by brick of thoughtfully curated #AIUseCases and developed #AISkills.
‚û¢ Your board is watching. 85% of companies now consider gen AI a top 5 priority. Can you articulate your strategy? Does it track to your firm's AI Maturity Curve?
‚û¢ Rethink BASICS. AI requires changes to business processes, talent strategies, and organizational structures. Half-measures won't cut it. Thoughtful change management will radically improve success rates.
‚û¢ Lead from the front. Model commitment to AI adoption and openly share how you're developing strategy and mitigating risks. Your team will follow your lead.

The message is clear: AI is separating the leaders from the laggards. It's not too late, though early adopters are starting to pull ahead.

What side of the AI competitive moat will you be on?

‚Äª ‚Äª ‚Äª ‚Äª ‚Äª

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

data.text:
AI's getting creative, but don't fire your marketing team just yet. üé®ü§ñ 
 
A new study[1] shows ChatGPT-4 outperforming humans in open-ended creative tasks. But here's the kicker - the most creative humans still beat the bots in idea diversity. 
 
Key takeaways for execs: 
‚û¢ AI + Human beats AI alone. But only if you know how to play nice with the robots. 
‚û¢ Gender matters. Women's creativity dipped when competing against AI. Men? Not so much. Time to tailor your AI training. 
‚û¢ AI can strategize, but humans still reign supreme in optimization. For now. 
‚û¢ People are biased against AI-generated work... even when they can't tell the difference. ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è 
‚û¢ Not all AI is created equal. ChatGPT-4 crushed it. Bard? Not so much. Choose your AI dance partner to match your song and style. 
 
Bottom line: AI's a powerful creative collaborator, not a replacement. Your competitive edge? Knowing how to leverage both silicon and carbon-based creativity. 
 
Don't just give your team AI access. Teach them to tango with it. üíÉü§ñ 
 
P.S. Ladies, you got this. üí™ Why are so many studies coming out showing women use AI less or less effectively? 
 
‚Äª ‚Äª ‚Äª ‚Äª ‚Äª

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

data.text:
Leaders need to understand (and utilize) useful AI interaction patterns. Recent research[1] highlights "extraheric AI" - a framework designed to foster higher-order thinking skills.  
 
Here are key interaction strategies organizations should consider: 
 
1. Suggesting & Recommending - AI proposes multiple ideas or solutions, encouraging users to evaluate and choose. 
2. Explaining - AI offers detailed rationales, promoting deeper understanding of complex topics. 
3. Nudging - Subtle AI-driven cues guide users toward exploring diverse perspectives. 
4. Debating & Discussing - AI agents engage users in dialogue, challenging assumptions and broadening viewpoints. 
5. Questioning - AI poses thought-provoking queries, stimulating critical thinking and reflection. 
6. Scaffolding - AI provides structured support, gradually reduced as user competence grows. 
7. Simulating - AI creates scenarios for users to practice skills or experience different viewpoints. 
8. Demonstrating - AI models processes or behaviors, allowing users to learn through observation. 
 
These strategies aim to enhance cognitive engagement rather than replace human thinking. The goal? A workforce that leverages AI to think more critically, creatively, and comprehensively. 
 
As the article highlights, there are plenty of gaps in applying these concepts. That means your team can gain a significant competitive advantage by implementing them wisely. 
 
Which patterns are you already using? Which strategy intrigues you most? 
 
‚Äª ‚Äª ‚Äª ‚Äª ‚Äª

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

data.text:
New research on generative AI adoption[1] confirms: if you're not strategically implementing AI, you're falling behind. Fast. 
 
Key findings that underscore the importance of a structured AI ROI approach: 
 
‚û¢ 28% of workers use AI at work, with 1 in 9 using it daily 
‚û¢ Usage spans all sectors - even 22% of blue collar workers report using AI 
‚û¢ Employers need to bridge usage across demographics - women are 50% less likely to use AI than men (!!) 
 
The data is clear: AI isn't coming, it's here. But haphazard adoption risks widening workplace inequalities. 
 
Don't leave your AI strategy to chance. A systematic approach to use cases, risks, skills, and mastery loops isn't just smart - it's essential for staying competitive. 
 
‚Äª ‚Äª ‚Äª ‚Äª ‚Äª 
üì¨ If this post is helpful or insightful, please comment or repost.

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

data.text:
AI hype ‚â† AI strategy (and employees can tell). Here's the deal: Shadow AI is rampant in your (every) organization whether you like it or not.  
 
Your employees are already using ChatGPT to draft emails, generate code, and who knows what else. So why not own it? 
 
A clear AI strategy isn't just a fancy PowerPoint for the board. It's your investment in the compounding benefits of #AIMastery. Here's why it matters: 
 
üïµÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Tame the Shadow AI beast: 74% of ChatGPT accounts used at work are personal. That's a lot of uncontrolled AI shenanigans. A strategy helps focus and align usage while mitigating #AIRisks. 
 
ü§ù Build trust, not panic: Employees are less likely to fear the AI boogeyman coming for their jobs when they know the plan. 
 
üöÄ Start simple, scale smart: Your first AI strategy doesn't need to cure cancer. Start with clear, achievable #AIUseCases. You will level up as you achieve mastery and scale the AI maturity curve. 
 
Remember, a half-baked AI strategy is like bringing a spork to a gunfight. It might look cute, but it won't do jack in the real world. 
 
Don't let your competition outpace you while debating whether to allow ChatGPT. Get clear with leadership, brainstorm with employees, then articulate your strategy. Your employees (and your bottom line) will thank you. 
 
‚Äª ‚Äª ‚Äª ‚Äª ‚Äª 
üì¨ If this post is helpful or insightful, please comment or repost.

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

data.text:
I'm excited (and a little nervous) to announce my most recent passion project: the AI ROI Playbook. 

I created a self-paced course for executives and senior leaders to help define their gen AI strategy. The course covers:

1) Brainstorming & prioritizing AI Use Cases
2) Understanding & mitigating AI Risks
3) Training & developing AI Skills
4) Establishing AI Mastery loops

I'm a firm believer that gen AI is radically changing the pace and quality of work. Used effectively, an individual contributor can scale meaning and impact in the workplace. But ... 

Change is hard. Employees are scared about losing their jobs. Leaders are feeling the pressure (and FOMO). There is just so much noise and hype in AI land, it's hard to know how to move forward.

The 4-step AI ROI Playbook is for leaders who need a coherent, future-proof AI strategy.

Learn more here: www.AIROIPlaybook.com
The first 20 sign ups get 50% off with coupon code: first20

If you have any questions or thoughts, comment below or send me a DM.

I'm excited to get this live and see what y'all think!

Side note: all of your methods sections are becoming instruction manuals.

author.headline: Associate Professor at The Wharton School. Author of Co-Intelligence

data.text:
In a business setting, this suggests the critical importance of well-documented processes. These "methods" are sometimes found in training or onboarding but more often in oral institutional knowledge.

As we lean into paradigms of co-intelligence (Ethan Mollick) and collective intelligence (Gianni Giacomelli), the ability to accurately articulate systematic thinking is a critical #AISkill to train.

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

resharedPost.text:
In this post, I tried to lay out, in a non-technical way, where we are in the development of AI, the state of the top five AI models available now, & what the near future of AI is going to be.

The short answer is that LLMs are going to keep getting better. https://lnkd.in/eFKdVfFq

author.headline: Associate Professor at The Wharton School. Author of Co-Intelligence

data.text: Good summary for those interested in understanding how OpenAI's recent o1 launch bridged from "training" inference to "thinking" inference in model scale.

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

data.text:
OpenAI's new o1 model is better at reasoning. Does that mean humans will "fall asleep at the wheel" more?

Great analysis by Ethan Mollick[1] highlighting how he felt more disconnected from the answer. And Professor Mollick is an expert who literally does this for a living - when a junior employee picks up this tool, how will we train them to keep them in the loop? How will they become experts if all the thinking and planning is done for them?

Awesome to see the amazing progress in models, and very important for us to stay focused on where and how humans guide the workflows in the meantime.

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

data.text:
Some great thoughts from Gianni Giacomelli about how gen AI can level up beginners across a broad array of skills and topics.

The power users and alpha adopters already see this value and use it natively. How can organizations systematize these #AISkills to ensure organizations experience the compounding benefits of this "beginner level up"?

I always advocate for defining #AIUseCases and tackling from that angle, though curious to hear how others approach realizing the value of AI in their firms.

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

article.title: Can AI Make Us Great Beginners at Everything?
article.subtitle: Gianni Giacomelli

resharedPost.text:
After talking to many firms, I have come to believe a key factor in successful AI adoption is whether the executive team actually experiments with AI to try to get work done themselves. Those who do tend to feel urgency and push for transformation.

Most c-level folks (the vast majority of executives I talk to) still haven‚Äôt even tried LLMs. Changing that should be the highest priority of anyone who wants their company to succeed at AI.

author.headline: Associate Professor at The Wharton School. Author of Co-Intelligence

data.text: Couldn't agree more with this sentiment. For executive leaders to effectively lead AI initiatives, they need to prioritize using AI themselves.

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

data.text:
AI increases performance for beginners (a lot) and for experts (some, but not always). Key insights from a recent BCG study[1]:

#AIUseCases

‚Üí "Better beginners" - GenAI-augmented workers performed complex data science tasks at 86% of expert level, even without prior experience. Researchers dubbed this effect as generating better beginners, with some caveats on evaluation.
‚Üí "Brainstorm partner" - GenAI users were 15% more likely to apply advanced machine learning methods when tackling challenging predictive analytics. That suggested the AI was helpful in brainstorming approaches to a complex data problem.

#AISkills

‚Üí "Engineering mindset" - Moderate coding experience improved performance across all tasks‚Äîeven non-coding ones‚Äîby 10-20%. Cultivating the awareness of task decomposition and systematic workflows is key for anyone using AI.
‚Üí "Reskilling Paradox" While GenAI instantly boosted task performance, it didn't inherently increase knowledge retention, highlighting the need for intentional learning strategies.

#AIMastery

‚Üí "Review checkpoints" - Workers need enough domain knowledge to supervise AI outputs and recognize errors. When junior employees are given more complex tasks, they need regular reviews from experts to ensure accuracy and quality in their work.
‚Üí "Professional identity" - Knowledge workers should be encouraged to use AI as it adds to their value proposition. Cross-functional teams with easy access to experts are vital for growth and learning.

GenAI isn't just enhancing what we can do‚Äîit's redefining what's possible. Leaders must rethink talent acquisition, learning & development, and strategic workforce planning to harness this potential.

How are you "incentivizing and protecting time to learn" these AI tools in your organization? Let's discuss in the comments!

Kudos to Daniel Sack, Lisa Krayer, PhD, Emma Wiles, Mohamed Abbadi, Urvi Awasthi, Ryan Kennedy, Cristi√°n Arnolds, and Fran√ßois Candelon for their valuable research. Big thanks to Debbie Lovich for sharing the research and the larger Boston Consulting Group (BCG) team for prioritizing and participating in this research.

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

resharedPost.text:
We have increasing evidence that today's AIs can, indeed, generate novel ideas that can beat those of expert humans.

This paper shows that the AI generates better academic research ideas that are more novel and exciting (to other researchers!) than experts in the field, with no significant difference in the idea's feasibility. More signs that, when done right, AI might be able to improve academic research, or even conduct it, in the future. 

Paper: https://lnkd.in/eEQY3R6m

author.headline: Associate Professor at The Wharton School. Author of Co-Intelligence

data.text:
Gen AI is an effective partner for generating novel ideas. Human experts agree.

This paper focuses on NLP research topics, but the core concepts and proposed methodology can expand to any area of complex fields. 

I'm interested in senior leaders generating ideas for #AIUseCases that they can implement in their organization. This paper suggests that, with some limited examples and documentation, leaders can use AI tools (like, in this paper, Anthropic's Claude) to generate valuable ideas to prototype internally.

I would venture to say that, with the appropriate prompting and examples, Claude would also be valuable at citing #AIRisks and suggesting ways to mitigate them. Identifying #AISkills to realize those use cases is relatively easy, but developing or hiring in those skills is a completely other topic ...

All this points back to a simple truth: AI, used wisely, can be a force multiplier to augment human creative and implementation.

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

resharedPost.text:
Big paper I have been waiting for: what are the real impacts of AI on programmer productivity?

The research is a randomized controlled trial using the older, less-powerful GPT-3.5 powered Github Copilot for 4,867 coders in Fortune 100 firms.

It finds a 26.08% increase in completed tasks. Those are very large impacts from a new (and now outdated) tool.

Paper: https://lnkd.in/eKQ4CF6q

author.headline: Associate Professor at The Wharton School. Author of Co-Intelligence

data.text:
Coding is the tip of the spear when it comes to #AIUseCases with easy to quantify value. Great to see a randomly controlled trial validate the gains.

Also, aligned with what Ethan Mollick writes in his book, this paper reported more significant gains for more junior developers.

In the comments for Ethan's original post, some great discussion about not just marginal productivity gains but being able to do completely new engineering functions - like having a new qualified team member vs. accelerating existing team members.

As agents become more commonplace across knowledge worker trades, will be fascinating to see how the frontier of possibility continues to evolve.

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

data.text:
Informative conversation from Clara Shih on a recent McKinsey & Company podcast. [1]

I especially liked the points about CIOs, CROs, and CMOs focusing on trust, outcomes, and people concerning AI implementations.

And couldn't agree more with value of a beginner mindset. Things are changing fast, though many fundamentals around managing change remain constant. Keeping an open and curious mind will serve leaders well.

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

resharedPost.text:
AI is new but the root causes for AI project failure are not

By some estimates, more than 80 percent of AI projects fail ‚Äî twice the rate of failure for information technology projects that do not involve AI.

The RAND Corporation conducted a study to find out what is behind this high failure rate.

The study identified five root causes for failure that sound familiar : 

1)  Stakeholders often misunderstand or miscommunicate what problem needs to be solved.

2) Organizations lack the necessary data to adequately train an effective AI model.

3)  Organizational focuses too much on AI tech than on solving real problems.

4) Lack of adequate infrastructure to manage data and deploy completed AI models

5) AI is applied to problems that are too difficult for AI to solve.

The not so surprising recommendations from The RAND Corporation are: 

1) Ensure that technical staff understand the project purpose and domain context: 

2) Choose enduring problems: AI projects require time and patience to complete. 

3) Focus on the problem, not the technology.

4) Invest in infrastructure: Up-front investments in infrastructure to support data governance and model deployment can reduce the time required to complete AI projects and can increase the volume of high-quality data available to train effective AI models.

5) Understand AI's limitations: When considering a potential AI project, leaders need to include technical experts to assess the project's feasibility.

Revolutionary üòè 

See study below

author.headline: VP People & Culture

data.text:
This analysis on "Anti-Patterns of AI" from RAND by James Ryseff, Brandon De Bruhl, MPP, MA and Sydnes Newberry focuses primarily on ML applications of AI, but the conclusions are sound in the GenAI space as well.

Especially the recommendations around understanding #AIUseCases, AI limitations, and developing or hiring the right #AISkills to succeed.

Thanks for the share Nico Orie.

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

data.text:
ü§î Women are less likely than men to use Gen AI at work. Agree or disagree? 
 
This bold claim comes from a study in Denmark via the Economist.[1] 
 
The study goes on to say this is prevalent within the same firms, and may be a self-imposed ban by women. 
 
Is this a regional quirk? Are you seeing different adoption rates between your female and male colleagues?

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

data.text:
Requiring sharing #AIUseCases internally is brilliant. 
 
Each department head sources (and certifies) a list of #AIUseCases, which are then reviewed by senior leadership for risks and opportunities. 
 
Tons of cross-pollination opportunities and obvious wins for mitigating risks from unknown uses. 
 
https://lnkd.in/gQBc27Us

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

article.title: White House Issues Guidance on Federal AI Use Reporting Requirements
article.subtitle: executivegov.com

data.text:
Asking junior employees about GenAI is not a strategy. Leaders are experts, and they need to take ownership for defining GenAI strategies for their organizations.

This paper[1] from MIT Sloan School of Management and lead researcher Kate Kellogg highlights some of the challenges of relying on junior employees, especially regarding #AIRisks.

Leaders - creating an AI strategy doesn't have to be daunting or overwhelming. But it is critically necessary. 

"Shadow AI," using personal AI accounts outside of company protections, is widespread. 74% of ChatGPT accounts & 94% of Gemini accounts used at work are personal. [2]

So leaders, if you don't provide guidelines and guardrails, your employees will figure it out without your guidance. And there is definitely risk associated with that.

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

data.text:
4 inflection points of using GenAI strategically. Most companies don't get past #1.

1Ô∏è‚É£ Browser-based tools (e.g. Anthropic,
OpenAI)
**Strategic implication** Big spike in value, but limited competitive differentiation (everyone can use these tools for free!) until advanced task stacking.

Exp.üí∞ = Free to 100s

‚Ä¢ Beginner: Naive prompting
‚Ä¢ Intermediate: Advanced prompting, platform-specific tools (CustomGPTs, Artifacts, etc)
‚Ä¢ Advanced: Centralized prompt repositories for wide array of tasks, daisy chaining outputs between tools, multi-modal use

2Ô∏è‚É£ Model APIs (custom code or no-code tools)
**Strategic implication** Extending upon lessons learned from prompting in browser-based tools is not a huge leap. Once a team hits the edge of what's possible in browsers, this can add significant value and competitive differentiation while also adding #AIRisks. It requires more technical understanding and skills while opening more automation and sophistication.

Exp.üí∞ = Ks to 100Ks

‚Ä¢ Beginner: Scaling best-in-class workflows from browser learnings at a fraction of the cost
‚Ä¢ Intermediate: Adding new use cases not possible in browser, full trace tracking with continual audits, integrating into organizational workflows, simple chaining
‚Ä¢ Advanced: Advanced chaining, seamless integration into work systems, #AIRisk mitigation platform, managing costs by picking the best model for the specific task

3Ô∏è‚É£ Agentic workflows (including RAG and more)
**Strategic implication** Agents also use APIs but are orders of magnitude more risky, complex, and expensive to maintain. Especially when they take autonomous actions without human supervision, risks compound. And with great risk comes great rewards ... organizations that master agentic workflows are leaps and bounds ahead of the competition with a real technological moat of differentiation.

Exp.üí∞ = 10Ks to Ms

‚Ä¢ Beginner: NA
‚Ä¢ Intermediate: Integrate simple model API outputs to update records, perform actions, and create recommendations within internal systems for human review; agent auditing system
‚Ä¢ Advanced: Multiple autonomous agents with agent routing based on use case and context; real-time monitoring of agent actions with regular reporting to track efficacy, drift, and complications

4Ô∏è‚É£ Fine-tuning models 
**Strategic implication** Orders of magnitude more complex and expensive than agents. It only makes sense for larger businesses with sophisticated data teams and vast reams of custom data (and R&D budgets).

Exp.üí∞ = 100Ks to 10Ms

‚Ä¢ Beginner: NA
‚Ä¢ Intermediate: NA
‚Ä¢ Advanced: Building a fine-tuned model for a specific use case and systematically testing against leading foundational models.

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

article.title: Fight Health Insurance platform uses AI to appeal claim denials
article.subtitle: sfstandard.com

data.text:
A valuable #AIUseCase that I often hear is customer sentiment analysis. Here's one approach:

**Analyzing Sentiment in Customer Feedback**

Create a CSV of customer reviews, survey responses, or social media comments to feed the AI tool. Then, ask it to categorize the sentiment (positive, negative, neutral) and identify key themes or recurring issues.

Two prompting power moves:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Provide "multi-shot prompting" by adding examples in the prompt for each of the three types of sentiment categories. This will improve classification notably.
2Ô∏è‚É£ Request the AI to identify any outliers or anomalies in the sentiment data, which often reveal valuable insights.

Scoring this use case:

‚Ä¢ Prerequisites: Customer feedback data
‚Ä¢ Time to Value: Medium
‚Ä¢ Impact: High
‚Ä¢ Complexity: Medium
‚Ä¢ Risk: Low (some potential for bias)
‚Ä¢ Tooling: foundational models (browser-based for small volume or API for larger volume)
‚Ä¢ Vendors: OpenAI, Anthropic, etc - who else do you recommend for sentiment analysis?

--My Take--
üìä This use case offers valuable insights but requires careful interpretation.

Sentiment analysis can quickly process large volumes of customer feedback, providing a high-level view of customer satisfaction and identifying trends. It's particularly useful for tracking changes in sentiment over time or comparing sentiment across different product lines or customer segments.

However, it's important to remember that sentiment analysis tools can struggle with nuance, sarcasm, or cultural context. Combining AI-driven sentiment analysis with human review is crucial to catch these subtleties and ensure accurate interpretation.

The most important thing, of course, is what you do with that information! Where it's not obvious, armed with specific customer insights, you can ask your AI tooling for recommendations on how to improve your offering to alleviate these concerns.

How are you using AI for sentiment analysis? Has it improved your customer insights? Share your experiences and #AISkills tips in the comments!

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

author.headline: Go-to-market

data.text: Great team with a fast-growing company. Check it out!

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

data.text:
AI as Oil rapidly accelerating technological, social, and societal shifts is a powerful analogy by Packy McCormick [1]. I agree with the fundamentally optimistic outlook on "The Goldilocks Zone" while also acknowledging the many problems this general technology can create.

Professionally, I believe it's critically important to have hands-on learning with this power tool. The sooner we each know where (and where not) to use it, the better we can apply it to meaningful tasks.

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

data.text:
A practical #AIUseCase that's streamlining business development is AI-assisted proposal creation. Here's the approach:

**Crafting Winning Proposals**

Input the RFP requirements, client information, and our company's relevant capabilities. Then, use step-by-step and least-to-most reasoning to ask the AI to generate an outline and draft proposal sections. Work your way up the complexity offering feedback along the way.

Two prompting power moves:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Prime the AI by feeding examples of past proposals that your team has won.
2Ô∏è‚É£ Include call transcripts, past customer history, or other context to refine the language and specific needs of the customer.

Scoring this use case:

‚Ä¢ Prerequisites: RFP details, company info, past proposals, call transcripts, other context
‚Ä¢ Time to Value: Low
‚Ä¢ Impact: High
‚Ä¢ Complexity: Medium
‚Ä¢ Risk: Medium to high (depends on the industry)
‚Ä¢ Tooling: Foundational models; specialized proposal software
‚Ä¢ Vendors: Anthropic, OpenAI, Storydoc, Better Proposals - what other tools have you found effective?

--My Take--
üìù This use case can significantly reduce the time spent on proposal creation, but it's not a complete replacement for human expertise.

The AI's ability to quickly generate coherent, well-structured proposals based on given inputs is valuable. It's particularly useful for creating first drafts and addressing all RFP requirements.

Notable risks arise in regulated industries or big-ticket projects. In these cases, you may be better served using on-prem, fine-tuned models for your specific industry needs.

As always, this #AIUseCase only augments the human expert in the loop. AI can handle some menial content creation and provide a solid foundation. The most compelling proposals still require customization, strategic thinking, and a deep understanding of the client's needs that may not be fully captured in the initial inputs.

I expect to see dedicated solutions for specific verticals with nuanced needs and tons of historical data (e.g. DoD, construction, healthcare). It'll be important to keep training the specialized models on win and loss signals to improve first-draft outputs. For enterprises, ensuring data and model governance for sensitive materials is critical.

This is not the easiest use case to start with for anything beyond simple proposals. Those who focus on #AIMastery here will create significant competitive advantages by bidding and winning more projects faster.

How are you leveraging AI in your proposal creation process? Has it improved your win rates or efficiency? Share your experiences and #AISkills tips in the comments!

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

data.text:
Enjoyed @rexwoodbury's recent writings on AI. Some of my favorite quotes & insights:

In "Weapons of Mass Production"[1] Rex delineated distribution (railways & internet) from production (industrial factories & gen AI) to posit trends we can expect to see moving forward. 

üí¨ "What the industrial revolution was for atoms, the AI revolution is for bits."

He suggests that we'll see shifts in unit economics from subscription-based to usage-based models. Usage-based makes more sense from a consumer standpoint, but it creates volatility and a race to the bottom on pricing for software providers.

In "Egg Theory of AI Agents"[2] Rex points to "enough friction" being a good thing to provide comfort to humans making the decisions. I've posted in the past that augmentation feels more palatable than automation, and the question is how many "eggs" do we need to add to feel enough of the process?

Great points and insights for those building with AI. Definitely early days and lots of potential #AIUseCases that will only emerge in the coming years.

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

data.text:
@company_MITedu published an #AIRisk repository [1] with over 700 documented risks. Pre-print and database are available for free online.

Admitting there is a (potential) problem is the first step to mitigating and safeguarding. Greate to see this work.

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

data.text:
A consistent trend that common #AIUseCases that drive value are workflow automation, content creation, and GTM (marketing, sales, customer success) motions.

What tasks or content is your team doing manually today that could be streamlined or automated?

Chart from an Inc. Magazine CEO survey [1].

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

resharedPost.text:
üìñ Words carry a lot of weight: The AI I'd like to see is Amplified Intelligence.

‚ö°Ô∏è While at Tesla, my team title was "Service Automation." 

üí° This seemingly innocuous term made me think a lot: my position was that when we used the word "automation," people on the other side of the table would immediately assume we were planning to replace them with robots. 

üóØÔ∏è To address this misconception, we shifted our language and started using "augmentation" instead.

By framing our work as "intelligence amplification," we conveyed a more nuanced and positive message. 

Rather than suggesting that AI would make human workers obsolete, we emphasized how AI could enhance human capabilities. 

The idea was to position AI as a tool that empowers employees to do more faster and better. 

In essence, we were advocating for a future where humans and machines work together in harmony.

üîô This term is not new. 

The concept of intelligence amplification (IA) first emerged in the 1950s and 1960s, proposed by pioneers in cybernetics and early computing.

Maybe we have to go back to it. 

This represents a paradigm shift from replicating human intelligence to amplifying it,

True AI is about augmenting human intelligence. üí´

https://lnkd.in/eubt9KjY

#Artificial Intelligence #AI #Disruption #Innovation

author.headline: Solving meaningful problems through technology | AI - Disruption - Education - Sustainability - Angel Investor

data.text:
Words matter.

I understand the history of "artificial" and couldn't agree more that "amplified" is the right angle on empowering and augmenting humans at work.

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

data.text:
Yup, defining #AIROI is hard. [1]

That's why it's so important to start with a clear AOI strategy with defined #AIUseCases and a plan for training #AISkills.

Without that, the knee jerk of giving then removing a power tool will burn employee trust and good will.

Stats are from a Hewlett Packard Enterprise survey [2], and it's understandable that these "strategic outcomes" are hard to pin down with a dollar number. Hard, but not impossible ...

Not sure how I'd use this for work purposes, and still fun to play.

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

data.text:
To use AI to generate content, you need a clear and concise Brand Voice document. Making that doc is a great #AIUseCase.

Here's my approach to using AI for brand voice development:

**Crafting a Consistent Brand Personality**
I input key brand attributes, target audience details, and existing marketing materials. Then, I ask the AI to analyze the existing materials to tell me the patterns it observes. If starting net new, you can also share examples from other creators that you like and want to emulate.

Two prompting power moves:
1Ô∏è‚É£ I ask it to create a "brand voice guide" with do's and don'ts, example phrases, and tone descriptors.
2Ô∏è‚É£ I use AI to "translate" existing content into the new brand voice, helping to visualize the transformation.

Scoring this use case:
‚Ä¢ Prerequisites: Existing materials or examples, target audience info
‚Ä¢ Time to Value: Low
‚Ä¢ Impact: Medium
‚Ä¢ Complexity: Low
‚Ä¢ Risk: Low
‚Ä¢ Tooling: Large language models
‚Ä¢ Vendors: Start simple with OpenAI or Anthropic

--My Take--
üé≠ This use case demonstrates AI's potential in creative processes, but it requires an iterative approach.

AI can quickly generate variations in tone and style, allowing brands to experiment with different voices efficiently. It's useful for ensuring consistency across various marketing channels and content types.

Be skeptical and critical if the suggestions don't align with the brand's core values and personality. I've found it's crucial to use AI for inspiration and refinement, rather than relying on it entirely for voice creation.

The key to #AIMastery here is generating lots of suggestions and melding those with your personal understanding and intuition. It's about augmenting, not replacing, the human touch in brand development.

Once you're done, you can use this document to generate your downstream content.

Have you used AI to develop a brand voice? Share your experiences and #AISkills tips in the comments!

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

resharedPost.text:
AI is not hype. Let's talk about AI productivity gains. 
 
Walmart CEO on using AI in their latest earnings: 
 
"We've used multiple LLMs to accurately create or improve over 850,000,000 pieces of data in the catalog. Without the use of generative AI, this work would have required nearly 100X the current headcount to complete in the same amount of time" 
 
These are some of the use cases he mentioned: 
 
1. Improvement of Product Catalog: Using generative AI to accurately create or improve over 850 million product catalog data pieces. 
 
2. Order Picking: AI assists associates in picking online orders by showing high-quality product packaging images to help them quickly find what they're looking for. 
 
3. AI-Powered Search: Customers and members benefit from AI-powered search on Walmart's app and site. 
 
4. Shopping Assistant: A new AI shopping assistant provides advice and ideas, answering customer questions like "Which TV is best for watching sports?" 
 
5. Follow-up Questions: The AI assistant is being developed to respond to more specific follow-up questions, such as "How's the lighting in the room where you'll place the TV?" 
 
6. Supporting Sellers on Marketplace: AI helps sellers on Walmart‚Äôs marketplace by improving their experience and helping them grow their businesses. 
 
7. Testing New Experience for Sellers: A new experience is being tested for U.S.-based sellers that allows them to ask AI anything, focusing on making the selling experience seamless. 
 
8. Summarizing and Answering Queries: The AI assistant provides concise answers to sellers without requiring them to sort through long articles or other materials. 
 
The sooner you begin moving quickly, learning, and iterating, the sooner you'll start transforming your business and integrating AI across all operations.  
 
Companies that fail to do this will inevitably face disruption.

author.headline: building AI systems

data.text:
A bunch of #AIUseCases from one of the largest companies that has tremendous volume and resources to invest in gen AI tooling and skills.

What truly amazes me is that #AIROI and developing #AISkills to improve margins are directly accessible to SMBs and mid-market companies with a fraction of the budget of Walmart.

Part of getting there is a mindset shift to work with AI. A bigger part is developing a thoughtful strategy that identifies use cases to target and empowering + training the individuals who will help get there. And the biggest part is just getting started! Plenty of access to free tools to play around today.

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB

data.text:
I've been playing with Claude for Sheets[1] from Anthropic and it's pretty awesome for testing prompts + using formulas to augment outputs.

Definitely lose some serious functionality from browser Claude (projects, artifacts, back & forth), but it's a nice half-way step to coding manually via the API. 

Much better for generating copy in bulk.

*Pro Tip* Make sure to hard paste any output you want to keep. I've had cells recalculate on me (=lose the output).

Any power users of Claude for Sheets that can share best practices? I saw in the reviews that caching can become an issue, but haven't bumped into it myself yet.

author.headline: GTM Ops | Gen AI strategy | Stanford GSB
